trans-unit.source: Represents a combination of <xref href="System.Windows.Media.FontFamily"></xref>, <xref href="System.Windows.FontWeight"></xref>, <xref href="System.Windows.FontStyle"></xref>, and <xref href="System.Windows.FontStretch"></xref>.
A typeface is a single variation of a font within the same font family.
An example of a typeface is an italic version of the "Times New Roman" font family.
Typeface defines the weight, style and stretching features of a font.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref> class for the specified font family typeface name.
The typeface name for the specified font family.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref> class for the specified font family name, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Style*>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Weight*>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Stretch*> values.
The font family of the typeface.
The style of the typeface.
The relative weight of the typeface.
The degree to which the typeface is stretched.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref> class for the specified font family name, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Style*>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Weight*>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Stretch*> values.
In addition, a fallback font family is specified.
Passing `null` for the `fallbackFontFamily` parameter causes box characters to be displayed for characters not included in the primary font family.
The font family of the typeface.
The style of the typeface.
The relative weight of the typeface.
The degree to which the typeface is stretched.
The font family that is used when a character is encountered that the primary font family (specified by the `fontFamily` parameter) cannot display.
Gets the distance from the baseline to the top of an English capital letter for the typeface.
A return value of `1` indicates that the top of an English capital letter is one font em above the baseline, while a return value of `0.5` indicates that it is half a font em above the baseline.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the distance from the baseline to the top of an English capital letter, expressed as a fraction of the font em size.

Gets a value that indicates whether the current typeface and the specified typeface have the same <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.FontFamily*>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Style*>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Weight*>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface.Stretch*>, and fallback font values.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref> to compare.
if o is equal to the current object; otherwise, .
If o is not a object, is returned.
Gets a collection of culture-specific names for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.LanguageSpecificStringDictionary"></xref> value that represents the culture-specific names for the typeface.
Gets the name of the font family from which the typeface was constructed.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.FontFamily"></xref> from which the typeface was constructed.
Serves as a hash function for <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
It is suitable for use in hashing algorithms and data structures such as a hash table.
An <xref:System.Int32> value that represents the hash code for the current object.
Determines whether to simulate a bold weight for the glyphs represented by the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface> can simulate a bold weight by stretching a glyph.
A non-simulated bold typeface is typically designed to have a better visual appearance than a simulated bold typeface.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if bold simulation is used for glyphs; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Determines whether to simulate an italic style for the glyphs represented by the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface> can simulate an italic style by shearing, or slanting, a glyph.
A non-simulated italic typeface is typically designed to have a better visual appearance than a simulated italic typeface.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if italic simulation is used for glyphs; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the stretch value for the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
The stretch value determines whether a typeface is expanded or condensed when it is displayed.
A font stretch value describes the degree to which a font form is stretched from its normal aspect ratio, which is the original width to height ratio specified for the glyphs in the font.
A <xref href="System.Windows.FontStretch"></xref> value that represents the stretch value for the typeface.
Gets a value that indicates the distance from the baseline to the strikethrough for the typeface.

A return value of `0.1` indicates that the strikethrough position is one-tenth of a font em above the baseline, while a return value of `0.25` indicates that its one-fourth of a font em above the baseline.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the strikethrough position, measured from the baseline and expressed as a fraction of the font em size.
Gets a value that indicates the thickness of the strikethrough relative to the font em size.

A return value of `0.05` indicates that the strikethrough thickness is one-twentieth of the font em size, while a return value of `0.1` indicates that the strikethrough thickness is one-tenth of the font em size.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the strikethrough thickness, expressed as a fraction of the font em size.
Gets the style of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
Three terms categorize the slant of a font: normal, oblique, and italic.
A <xref href="System.Windows.FontStyle"></xref> value that represents the style value for the typeface.
Retrieves the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GlyphTypeface"></xref> that corresponds to the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Typeface"></xref>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GlyphTypeface> is font face that directly corresponds to a font file on the disk.
A <xref:System.Windows.Media.Typeface>, however, is a representation of font face.

<xref href="System.Windows.Media.GlyphTypeface"></xref> object that corresponds to this typeface, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> if the typeface was constructed from a composite font.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the out parameter is set to a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GlyphTypeface"></xref> value; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates the distance of the underline from the baseline for the typeface.
The return value is usually negative, to place the underline below the baseline.

For example, a return value of `-0.1` indicates that the underline position is one-tenth of a font em below the baseline, while a return value of `-0.25` indicates that it is one-fourth of a font em below the baseline.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the underline position, measured from the baseline and expressed as a fraction of the font em size.
Gets a value that indicates the thickness of the underline relative to the font em size for the typeface.

A return value of `0.05` indicates that the underline thickness is one-twentieth of the font em size, while a return value of `0.1` indicates that the underline thickness is one-tenth of the font em size.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the underline thickness, expressed as a fraction of the font em size.
Gets the relative weight of the typeface.
Weight differences are generally differentiated by an increased stroke or thickness associated with a given character in a typeface, as compared to a "normal" character from that same typeface.
**Note** Not all weights are available for all typefaces.
When a weight is not available for a typeface, the closest matching weight is returned.
A <xref href="System.Windows.FontWeight"></xref> value that represents the relative weight of the typeface.
Gets the distance from the baseline to the top of an English lowercase letter for a typeface.
The distance excludes ascenders.

A return value of `0.25` indicates that the top of an English letter is one-fourth of a font em above the baseline, while a return value of `0.75` indicates that the top of an English letter is three-fourths of a font em above the baseline.
A <xref:System.Double> that indicates the distance from the baseline to the top of an English lowercase letter (excluding ascenders), expressed as a fraction of the font em size.
